abstract: Banks are making money hand over fist in the era of low interest rates. Savers, however, are making next to nothing, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.
snippet: Banks are making money hand over fist in the era of low interest rates. Savers, however, are making next to nothing, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Aren’t low short-term interest rates wonderful? If you are a bank, the answer is yes, particularly because the low rates are accompanied by somewhat higher longer-term rates. If you are a saver, however, your view might be very different, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline.main: Norris: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
